params.text:
It may not be possible to adapt your communication style to every culture within your workplace, but it is possible to adapt this particular style in a culturally sensitive manner.

Let’s have a look at the strategies for giving developmental feedback in English.
Click on each of the above examples to learn more
How can you provide developmental feedback in a meaningful and respectful way?

Creating a comfortable environment for feedback is essential to foster open communication and mutual respect between both parties. When individuals feel at ease, they are more likely to engage constructively, share honest perspectives, and collaborate effectively towards improvement. 

It is advisable to schedule a meeting ahead of time and provide a goal or an agenda, for example: to review the past two months to discuss the next steps. 

You can start the meeting with one of these lines:

  • “In our discussion today, I want to make sure that we all find opportunities to thrive and be successful in our roles”.
  • “My goal today is to help you feel confident in your skills.”
  • “I want to see you perform this task successfully and I am here to support your growth.”
  • “We are here to find solutions together and I want to hear your thoughts”.

Your browser does not support this audio
Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Use neutral, unemotional, calm tone of voice when sharing your thoughts. Remember that our goal is to reassure someone that you are there to help them improve in a specific area of growth, performance or skill. An accusatory tone will be counterproductive and will create tension. One way to do it- avoid using the word “you”, when pointing out opportunities for improvement.

Example: you have a team worker who struggles to handle upset customers.


Wrong feedback: “I see you are having some difficulty handling upset customers.”


Appropriate feedback: “I see that handling upset customers is a challenge.” This way there is no blame or accusation.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio
Your browser does not support this audio
Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Note: If you wish to hear just the verbatim again, click on the sound icon for individual sentence voiceovers after each verbatim.
Click here to go back and learn more

Example: in your team you expect everyone to give regular progress updates, which allows everyone on the team to know what’s happening and who is doing what. Perhaps a new team member is not doing it because in their old job, they were expected only to communicate the end result.

Wrong feedback: “You must give a weekly progress update to the team. By not doing it, you disrupt the workflow”.

Appropriate feedback: “As a team, we work best when we know how everyone is doing and where they are in their progress. Going forward, please share a weekly update, so we can all be on the same page.”

Avoiding imperatives: "I think the presentation could benefit from additional data to support the key points. For example, statistics or case studies to strengthen our argument and make it more convincing to our audience.

What do you think about exploring some additional data points for the next draft?"

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Avoiding imperatives: "I've observed that there have been instances where interruptions occur during our meetings, which can disrupt the flow of discussion.

How do you think we could create a more inclusive environment for communication to ensure everyone has the opportunity to share their thoughts without interruption?"

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
It is important to reassure others that they are supported, heard and seen by you. You can reiterate that they are doing well and you are looking forward to those improvements you have discussed together.

Example: "Alex, I want to recognize your outstanding effort on our recent project. Your creativity and attention to detail have really made a difference. While there's room for improvement, know that I'm here to support you. I believe in your potential and can't wait to see you grow."

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Here are some additional examples

"I appreciate the effort you put into this project."

"Thank you for your dedication and hard work on this task. Your commitment is truly appreciated."

"I want to recognise the time and energy you've invested in this project. Your efforts have not gone unnoticed."

"One area where I think there's room for improvement is..."

"While the overall quality of your work is commendable, I think there's an opportunity for refinement in this specific aspect."

"I've noticed that there are some inconsistencies in your approach. Let's work together to address these and elevate your performance."

"I'm here to support you in making these improvements."

"Please know that I'm here to assist you in any way I can as you navigate these challenges. Please reach out for support."

"If you need additional resources or guidance to improve in this area, I'm more than willing to provide the necessary support and assistance."

"I believe in your ability to overcome these challenges."

"I have full confidence in your ability to overcome obstacles and succeed in this endeavour. Your track record speaks for itself."

"Your past achievements demonstrate your capability and resilience. I'm confident that you'll rise to the occasion once again."

"I see great potential in you, and I'm excited to see how you continue to grow."

"Your dedication to self-improvement is admirable, and I'm eager to witness your continued growth and development."

"I see a hunger for learning and improvement in you that is truly inspiring. Keep pushing yourself, and I am confident you'll achieve great things."

facebookShare.quote: I scored @score out of @maxScore on a task at @currentpageurl.

twitterShare.statement: I scored @score out of @maxScore on a task at @currentpageurl.
